question_text: Why do multichannel minireactors outperform conventional fixed-bed reactors in CO₂ methanation, particularly in terms of heat management and reaction efficiency?
standard_answer: Multichannel minireactors excel over conventional fixed-bed reactors in CO₂ methanation due to superior heat and mass transfer characteristics. The exothermic nature of methanation (ΔH = -164.63 kJ/mol) can cause hot spots in fixed-beds, leading to catalyst deactivation, reduced selectivity, and safety risks. Minireactors feature small channel diameters (e.g., in multichannel designs), which enhance surface-to-volume ratios, improving heat dissipation to cooling surfaces and minimizing temperature gradients. This prevents localized overheating and maintains isothermal conditions, crucial for controlling side reactions like RWGS. Mass transfer is also enhanced through shorter diffusion paths, ensuring efficient reactant-catalyst contact and higher volumetric productivity. For example, a multichannel minireactor achieved 96.1% CO₂ conversion and >99% CH₄ selectivity at 350°C and 15 bar, handling 820 Nm³/h CO₂ per m² of channel, outperforming fixed-beds where hot spots are inevitable even with dilution. The compact design allows for better scalability and integration with heat recovery systems, making it ideal for high-intensity exothermic processes.
